awd_titl_txt: Standard: The Social Responsibilities of Scientists and Engineers: A Global Survey
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader social responsibilities that scientists and engineers feel regarding society and the larger communities of which they are members (i.e., their views about what their work can and should do to help society and the environment) are an important but understudied aspect of scientific practice and ethics. There is no consensus inside or outside of the scientific and engineering communities about the nature, scope, and sources of such social responsibilities. This research project will conduct an international survey of scientists and engineers regarding: (1) their beliefs about their social and ethical responsibilities to society; (2) how they arrive at these beliefs; (3) the challenges and opportunities they feel affect their ability to fulfill their social responsibilities; and (4) the ways in which their attitudes and opinions differ by factors such as discipline, job sector, age, gender, institutional type, and region. The investigators will team up with overseas scientific and engineering organizations to reach a global sample of scientists and engineers from a wide variety of disciplines, nations, and cultures. This research builds directly on an earlier NSF funded study that generated a robust, pre-tested survey instrument, translated it into five languages, and created a process for recruiting a globally representative sample of scientists and engineers.

This research project involves administering a quantitative survey to 12,500 scientists and engineers around the world. The main aim is to procure a globally representative sample of 4,000 scientists and engineers and to gauge their opinions and attitudes about their social and ethical responsibilities to society. Doing so will enable the investigators to generate data and knowledge about how scientists and engineers from around the world perceive their social responsibilities, and how these are informed by factors such as national background, disciplinary affiliation, and other demographic characteristics. This project will advance research on scientific and engineering ethics in three main ways. First, it broadens the scope of social studies of scientific and engineering ethics beyond the university and laboratory to consider wider kinds of social responsibilities. Second, studying the factors that determine and shape scientists' and engineers' opinions also enables understanding of how to encourage members of these communities to be more socially responsible in their work. Finally, this study will provide important new tools (i.e. survey items, a global sampling protocol) for advancing future international studies of scientific ethics. Findings and data will be disseminated nationally and internationally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientists and engineers have responsibilities that are internal to their professional communities, to their peers, to their research subjects, to funders, and to publishers. These responsibilities are, for the most part, well defined and well known among scientists and engineers. The same cannot be said of the external responsibilities that scientists and engineers hold to society broadly, that is, their “social responsibilities”. About these responsibilities there is no consensus among scientists and engineers or the wider public.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the particular importance of the relationship between science and society and made more pressing the need to understand the responsibilities held by scientists and engineers to the broader society. To contribute to that understanding, over the course of three years, the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) Scientific Responsibility, Human Rights and Law Program undertook a project aimed at learning what scientists and engineers themselves believe to be their responsibilities, why, and the context in which those responsibilities are, or are not, exercised. It also explored ways of better supporting scientists and engineers in the exercise of their social responsibilities.

The project had two parts to it. The first part involved a global survey. The survey asked questions addressing the views of scientists and engineers on their social responsibilities, what influenced their beliefs, and what influenced their ability to fulfill those responsibilities. To conduct the survey, AAAS partnered with 18 scientific and engineering societies, most of which were in the United States and some overseas. The survey was designed so that differences, for example, by gender, age, discipline, or sector, could be analyzed. The second part of the project involved interviews and a focus group. It used the findings from the survey as a starting point to narrow in on the perspectives of leading scientists and engineers and related influencers in the United States, specifically, including with regard to how best to support scientists and engineers to fulfill their responsibilities to society.

In total, 4,789 responses to the survey were analyzed out of 134,388 people that were sent it. Because of the relatively low number of responses, the findings of the survey cannot be understood to represent scientists and engineers, generally, but do suggest patterns of potential interest and value worthy of further exploration. For example, the top five most important social responsibilities chosen by survey participants were mitigate personal biases in your research and when offering expert advice;

  1. Foster the interests of young generations in science and engineers;
  2. Take steps to prevent or minimize the risks to society associated with the conduct of your work/research;
  3. Promote public access to scientific and technical information;
  4. When it comes to your attention, address any improper use of your research findings or products by others;

A particular influence on the views of those who participated in the study were mentors, as well as colleagues and peers. In contrast, codes of ethics, which are often developed by professional scientific or engineering societies to help guide the actions of their discipline, were reported as not having impact in shaping the views or actions of participants in practice. The results of the study suggest that opinions with regard to social responsibilities may differ based on, for example, the discipline in which a scientist or engineer works (for example, whether they are a life, behavioral and social scientist as compared to an engineer, mathematician, or statistician). Other differences were also suggested based on employment sector (for example, academia, government or industry), gender, and age. Another finding worth mentions was that the views of those who participated in the survey about the importance of various social responsibilities were not matched by high levels of reported action.

The findings of the study suggest areas for future effort, including supporting mentors to be effective leaders among their peers and students on discussions and actions needed to address the social responsibilities of scientists and engineers. There is scope for educators and trainers to figure out how to effectively address social responsibilities in their classes to help shape understanding and guide future behavior. Scientific and engineering societies also have a role in creating guidance and tools for their members that will help build a culture of socially responsible science and engineering in their discipline.

The data from the study will be made publicly available so that this work can continue to be built upon in the future.
